primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The journey of Jesus to Calvary, framed as a 'grand and redeeming pageant' where Jesus encounters different human responses (curiosity, pity) while moving toward the cross.

tekstueel_bewijs: We are following our Lord on the road to Calvary
He was on his way, not driven but choosing to climb the steep red stairway

object.identificatie: Mercy and Redemption / The Throne of Mercy
tekstueel_bewijs: the throne of mercy and redemption
that the awful agony and death he faced might honor and glorify the father
he died for you and me
all human beings have a stake in this
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of the sacrifice but is frequently recruited to be a Subject of response.

tekstueel_bewijs: these women offered him the consolation of their tears
the father might glorify the Son in his death
helper.rol_van_god: God is both Sender and the one who glorifies (Helper) the Subject (Jesus).

tegenstander.identificatie: Herod / Sin / Human Indifference / Frivolous Curiosity
tekstueel_bewijs: Frivolous curiosity he would not honor
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: While Herod is a historical actor, he represents the 'foulest' power and the spiritual danger of God's silence.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The hearer's response to the Passion: moving from shallow emotion to total life-consecration.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer ('I' / 'We')
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon argues that because Jesus did Program 1, the hearer must now execute Program 2 to avoid the 'silence of God'.

voorbeelden_god_subject: He shall deliver thee in six troubles
the Lord Christ... will ever be women's redemption
voorbeelden_mens_subject: I plead for your earnest attention
You must live so that you can say

voorbeelden: we dare not let the Lord pass us by
he was desirous to see him
I do not want to do anything to make him silent
we know the answer even as we ask
Live so that you can say
found in their trouble a joy and peace they never knew

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon shifts from the 'Pouvoir' of Christ (His ability to save) to the 'Devoir' of the hearer (The demand for total surrender).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the historical silence (Jesus before Herod) to the existential threat of silence in the hearer's soul.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in 'total sacrifice' (S1) to avoid the 'silence' (S2).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; silence is presented as the ultimate form of divine rejection.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon begins with a strong Christocentric narrative (Grace) but concludes with heavy moralistic demands (Law/Devoir).

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Live so that you can say, 'Speak, Lord.'
God demands more. My life! My all!

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: choosing to climb the steep red stairway toward the throne of mercy

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The women are used as a model of devotion, though their pity is critiqued as insufficient, leading to a demand for a 'deeper' model of sacrifice.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Focus on Christ as the one who remains faithful when all (men and women) fail to understand the depth of the cross.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Creates a sense of spiritual urgency and potential inadequacy (fear of God's silence).
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is finished by Christ, but 'keeping' the relationship depends on the hearer's quality of service.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Redeeming Pageant' to the 'Demand for Sacrifice' is rhetorically smooth but theologically jarring.
spanning_punten: The contrast between 'Grace unknown' and 'God demands more'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: he died for you and me

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The hearer is told to 'Live so that...', implying they must find the power within themselves.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: High; sin leads to the 'monstrous character' of Herod or the 'shallow' response of the women.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully establishes Christ as the Subject of the Passion but fails to maintain Him as the Subject of the hearer's sanctification.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The hearer becomes the Subject of 'keeping God speaking'.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Make the Holy Spirit the Subject who opens the hearer's ears.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'Live so that you can say...', use 'The Spirit enables us to hear Him even in our failures.'

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: Hearer as the one who must offer a 'worthy sacrifice'.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Hearer as the 'Dry Tree' that is made green by Christ.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that our only 'worthy sacrifice' is accepting His.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how the Cross gives us the power to serve, rather than just the obligation.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The 'Silence of God' is a sufficiently heavy opponent.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The sermon correctly identifies the gravity of spiritual deadness.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.probleem: The Secondary Program (Ethics) threatens to overshadow the Primary (Soteriology) at the end.
narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Re-anchor the 'Total Sacrifice' in Christ's finished work as the source, not the condition.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon has a powerful narrative drive and a deep sense of the 'pathos' of the Passion, but it risks burdening the hearer with a weight of response that only grace can carry.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would praise the 'Silence' motif; Greimas reveals this motif is used to shift the burden of action to the hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the historical Herod; Greimas shows Herod functions as a 'Warning Sender' for the hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals the 'Subject-switch' in the final third of the sermon where the 'I' of the preacher takes over from the 'He' of the Gospel.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Silence of Jesus' as a semiotic void that the hearer is commanded to fill with 'Total Sacrifice'.
